author: @nitogorostizo16
text: Trans/queer people literally saved my life, I'll keep putting my life in the line for you whenever you need it, it's the least I can do.

author: @mariapaula3376
text: I'm a queer Latin-American immigrant (Colombo-Mexican) living in Toronto, Canada. I'm in the endeavour of wanting to understand multiple perspectives of what it means to be black in the world. Your views on blackness, history, political analysis and more have expanded my understanding of blackness and have made me a better and more profound person. Thank you for the work you do, Olay :)

author: @banonKING
text: 110% with Da'Shaun... these religious structures have to go.  They're our true shackles on the black mind in America

replies.author: @ohubigmad
replies.text: is liberation theology in the conversation? or is there a conversation about liberation theology

replies.author: @Firebird00500
replies.text:
I was raised conservative Christian and I also 110% agree. These people are the reason for this. I had to learn about the Tulsa Massacre from a FUCKING TV SHOW, decades after I should have been taught about this. We were taught about the systematic destruction of Native Americans, the Trail of Tears, Chinese immigrants being mistreated, Irish immigrants being mistreated. What we learned about black people? Slavery -> Civil War -> Reconstruction -> Segregation -> MLK and now all racism is solved. There was no mention of the hundreds of white mobs burning down black cities and driving black Americans out of their own neighborhoods. I remember slavery was also massively sugar-coated. What's ironic is if you said the same thing about human trafficking victims now that people say about them then, you'd be absolutely hated by most people. Imagine hearing a story about a child trafficked for sex and hard labor and saying "Well maybe they picked up some useful skills! It's not ALL bad". Like WHAT THE FUCK.

I'll give them one thing though. They more than anyone else taught me that Jesus is a lie. How could he be real if the people who wanted to drone-strike migrants say he answers their prayers? Doesn't sound like the NT Jesus I read about.

Thank you guys for this discussion. I'm obviously cis and white, found out I was bi a couple years ago, but I am so far away from people who have actually been punished or targeted because of LGBTQ+ hatred. I love hearing about this from a community who has had to deal with it.

replies.author: @Empathy_is_Logical
replies.text: So true. We need new ideas, not old bullshit baggage holding everyone back

replies.author: @nojusticenetwork9309
replies.text:
I don't agree with this take. I agree that religious institutions are very much a real problem but religion itself is not a problem. Spiritual guidance and well being can and does have a major impact for many  people and always have. Religion and spirituality has helped shaped cultures to what they are and the beauty and uniqueness of all these cultures is due in part to these people's faiths. 

There are many valid criticisms that can be laid on religion writ large, but many of them in actually really targeting the institutions formed around them and the people who abuse their impact and importance for personal power and gain.

replies.author: @Firebird00500
replies.text: @nojusticenetwork9309 Religion and spirituality have shaped cultures, and our appendix kept us alive when we were eating raw meat. But that doesn't mean either is useful now. In fact, both can turn toxic and deadly.

replies.author: @kaikaibee
replies.text: To paraphrase that old saying: When they came to Africa we had land and riches and they had Bibles. When they asked us to bow our heads in prayer and we opened our eyes they had the land and we had the Bibles

replies.author: @Brookejon3695
replies.text:
‚Äã@ohubigmadIt's a small part to my mind. That's just a tiny shot of lemonade made out of the mountains of lemons force-fed to the enslaved. Part of the suppression of revolt, revolution, and disobedience is forcing the people under your boot to adopt your religion. A religion that says we get our eternal reward in death, and the greater we suffer in life the greater our reward.

Shackles go beyond cold iron. These are mental.

replies.author: @Brookejon3695

King James Bible doesn't say anything about sexuality, yet many preachers and priests do. It's more to be against people who spew hate and reinforce actual religiousness in religions.

author: @20xx-mm-dd
text: "Queer joy is important" PREACH!!

author: @untitledanarchistseagullch1237
text: Glad to see the bourgie white-cisness of the gay marriage campaign called out from the start. It was such telling juxtaposition how, at the same time as the marriage campaign went from strength to strength, the Democrats refused to pass the Employment Non-Discrimination Act because a lot of them were worried it might also require trans people (gasp, pearl-clutch) to be treated like human beings.

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text: Gay issues are not trans issues any more than they are black issues specifically.  They are all completely different things which is weird why the T in LGBT is lumped in there to begin with as if they were the same thing.

replies.author: @untitledanarchistseagullch1237
replies.text:
@jhlfsc That's a really odd take. The whole reason that the T has its own letter is that it's not actually the same thing, though there is massive overlap between them, since there are trans people within every one of the other categories represented in the term.
The idea of separating the T from LGBT, it's worth noting, was floated as a strategy by the far-right Values Voter Summit some years ago in order to attack LGBT rights more generally.

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text:
@untitledanarchistseagullch1237¬† 
I'm genuinely not sure what's so odd about this?  I can't begin to get into the minds of why any right-wing organization does anything they do, but just because they were allegedly saying that trans issues should be separate from gay issues does not mean that the reasoning behind it is the same.
In my opinion, it's strange and honestly  less meaningful to lump two completely separate issues together.  
So far, it has only served to help people confuse and conflate issues of sexuality, sex and gender.
As I said....the fact that African-American, Jewish, Islamic, Latino, women (or any other at risk group) are specific groups with specific issues onto themselves does NOT mean they cannot individually stand in solidarity with other marginalized groups.  It just means that they are separate groups due to the specific nature of the issues each group faces individually.    Trying to force gay and trans issues together as if they were the same thing only serves to weaken those groups by enabling the general population to not recognize either as  individual people with individual issues at play in our society.

replies.author: @untitledanarchistseagullch1237
@untitledanarchistseagullch1237
replies.text: @ogBINARYGODThe point is that it got results for some people (easily the least marginalised segment of the LGBT community), whilst leaving everyone else high and dry, and it was promoted by people who constantly told working-class LGBT people, particularly trans people, that they'd eventually come back and help out, but actually threw the rest of the community under the bus at the first opportunity.

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text:
@untitledanarchistseagullch1237¬† 
So explain to me how either gay or trans people are weaker because they aren't lumped in with African Americans??
The right will have zero qualms attacking gay and/or trans people regardless of which other groups we attempt to hide them behind no matter what. 
The question isn't for fascists, it's for everyone else who cannot understand how or why these two groups are spoken about as one entity despite being completely different people with completely different issues.  
Just look at how many potential or actual allies still conflate and confuse sexuality with gender.  This is a direct result of having both groups together as if they were completely interchangeable.
I'm not sure how this is even remotely controversial?

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text:
@xBINARYGODx¬† 
This guy is just being a flame thrower for the sake of being contrarian.  As if "white" people were the only ones in committed relationships who were left with no heath insurance, no inheritance, and virtually no legal rights as any other heterosexual couple of any class or background were afforded at baseline. üôÑ

replies.author: @JuguAbus
replies.text:
‚Äã@jhlfsc Obviously the LGB and the T can be completely different issues, but you cannot completely seperate something that can merge together somehow. Yes, there are straight trans people, but not every single trans person is going to be straight. I'm an example of that. Same as not every gay person being trans, but there are  gay people that are trans. When we're talking about the LGB or the T it is important to merge them in together cause they can overlap for people.

I do not understand why you would say forcing gay and trans issues together would weaken those groups. People know that the T is not the same thing as the G, but that doesn't mean we can't have the T with everything else.

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text:
@JuguAbus 
First of all...I think you are way off base in your opinion about most people "obviously knowing the difference between gay and trans".  It does seem unvelievably ludicrious that anyone would confuse or conflate the two concepts, and yet people in our society do it CONSTANTLY.ü§¶
I also do not understand what you mean by saying "you cannot completely seperate something that can merge together somehow."?
Being black can "merge" with being gay, trans or both.  Being Jewish or Muslim can "merge" with being gay, trans or both.  Being Latino can "merge" with being gay, trans or both and yet all of these other identities are not lumped in with the LGBT acronym. That is why it is odd that those two distinct groups (which of course could overlap with each other, but no more so than with any other oppressed group) would be catagorized together under the same umbrella.
It's misleading and because they ARE all catagorized together as the same group, it is one of the main reasons why many people are still so ignorant about the specifics and obvious differences between them.

replies.author: @prozierozie5692
replies.text: You dint speak for us ‚Äã@jhlfsc

replies.author: @jhlfsc
replies.text:
@prozierozie5692 
Who is "us"?

replies.author: @prozierozie5692
replies.text: @jhlfsc Queer people

author: @SuthernHippie
text: I can vividly remember in my early 20's being welcomed into the queer community through my co-worker and friend(I'm hetero). I loved that man, loved his partner, loved the love the community showed me. I never felt safer and more seen than I did when hanging with them and turning up in the club. Literally was given history lessons and dancing at the same time. Opened my mind to soooo much I never thought about. It shocks me that folks within the queer community ask me if I'm in the queer community. Just because I'm kind to them, and want to know them, know their humanity,  and genuinely ask questions to gain more perspective. I'm very much still and will always be learning, I'm checking anyone who talks crazy about the queer community. Especially my black queer fam, nahhhh because I'm definitely going toe to toe with that as*. Thank you for this convo!!

author: @PxsDD
text: This conversation about how to show up as very necessary and refreshing. I feel often that I‚Äôm not doing enough, but at the same time I have a family that I‚Äôm trying to support and raise up and teach and be a part of. The work that I do is in my every day life. My work is in being authentically and unabashedly me, and in learning what I can from spaces like this, staying up-to-date in the discourse, and bringing that knowledge to the people around me in my real life and calling out issues as I see them and letting people know where I stand. I think we do best to view ourselves as part of an ecosystem of revolution where all niches are valuable, from the each-one-teach-ones to the brick throwers. Great panel!

It's an all-or-nothing mentality. If they don't control everything, they feel like they control nothing at all (if only)

author: @kuyahdaemon
text:
Olay you're so incredible at moderating this conversation. I've always acknowledged that the freedoms I can experience as a gay Asian man have a through line that goes all the way back to black trans liberation. They have been fighting for freedom for ALL LGBTQIA+ folks. 

Great conversation, you guys really put out all out on the line. Also Hope's words are so powerful, she was spitting absolute truth! Thank you for extending this conversation past a singular Pride month. Much love!

author: @ongwehias7580
text: hearing affirmation of observations of our mutual oppressors and colonizers is valuable emotionally and confirmation of its veracity when our paths to the same conclusions were experienced in isolation from one another. its like how science works because you can replicate the results of the experiment in multiple places, changing hypothesis to theory.

author: @shawndomenico5830
text: Thanks Olay for bringing this panel together.  Great to hear from these Black queer & trans voices.

author: @AddiRockART
text: As a Latino, queer, trans artist, I‚Äôve been called hyperbolic and insane and crazy for having severe concerns since Obamas term was going to end. And now years later, people who had acquired privilege and are now being attacked are so shocked and disappointed‚Äî as a Latino, the attacks never stopped. The black community in Baltimore where I‚Äôm from, never stopped working, and sure as heck never stopped being barraged.

author: @hypnoamber3248
text:
Olay & Friends thank you!  This was such an amazing episode, so very important. I was happy to see Hope and Da'Shaun on the panel today. And what Da'Shaun said about revolutionary preparation stage at the end really got me thinking and I needed that. 

Again thank you to everyone on the panel today.

author: @StAmander
text: I‚Äôm white, trans, queer and disabled. There‚Äôs so many truths within this, not just the dynamic between queerness and blackness, especially for those of us who do not live in that intersection, but a lot of these themes in these many truths can be found in other marginalized groups and the dynamics between them. Like when the white cis queers were celebrating marriage equality or whatever, those of us who are disabled and low income were like, ‚ÄúThats nice you can get married, but we cannot if we don‚Äôt want to fall deeper into poverty, lose our homes, our medical care and subsequently our lives.‚Äù  Like I don‚Äôt need Allies who demand cookies and to be coddled (looking at specific media group who went centrist lately), I need accomplices who will not only do the work by putting their bodies on the line but to ultimately listen to us (or whatever marginalized group) and to ask us and listen to us (or whichever marginalized group) first and above others. I don‚Äôt want to be lectured by an ally about ‚Äúoptics‚Äù when they cannot understand the ‚Äúoptics‚Äù of when an ally repeatedly speaks over the majority of the marginalized people and attack them and those who are putting the work. Like I know what the optics are, I live it every fucking day; I just want to have equal rights and have Justice for all of the injustices we have faced, not to win some political bullshit. I‚Äôm glad I watched it, because even though this is more towards POC, it does help reaffirm my need to be in solidarity with POC and to work harder. The work isn‚Äôt done, we just started.

replies.author: @Robstafarian
replies.text: I feel you; I am disabled, white, and nonbinary (in chronological order). I am nearly 40, and I am beyond done with people asking me: "Don't you want to get married?"  All I have left is: "What makes you think I am allowed?"  Shout out to my brother a few years ago saying to me: "You sound like a minority." üíÄ

replies.author: @StAmander
replies.text: @Robstafarian  yeah it‚Äôs ridiculous. I deal with multiple disabilities, and right now the most debilitating one is the chronic pain I deal with. I didn‚Äôt have an actual choice on whether or not I will have back surgery, because if I didn‚Äôt comply pain management wouldn‚Äôt help me, and now I live with that fear since they want me to get a Neuro stimulation implant because the back surgery didn‚Äôt help with the pain. So now, I deal with the judgement addicts face on top of being denied medical treatment for the pain. It was easy in the beginning for me to be furious at the addicts, but I‚Äôve come to realize they are also dealing with chronic pain, it‚Äôs just a psychological pain rather than a physical or neurological pain, but it‚Äôs still pain, nonetheless and like chronic pain patient like myself, pharmaceutical grade medications like methadone and other opioids prescribed under the care of a physician is necessary, it is our medical treatment. They deserve to be humanized just as much as I do. I have to be in solidarity with them, because we are both throwing the bricks at the same people to borrow an analogy in this video. It just sucks to be a minority or sound like a minority, nobody wants to be like that.

replies.author: @Robstafarian
replies.text: @StAmander I do not mind being a minority: the oppression is the problem.

replies.author: @StAmander
replies.text: @Robstafarian  that is it. That is exactly it.

author: @GalihadVancouver
text:
This has to be my favorite video of yours so far! As a queer person, I also wasn't surprised when the ruling came down because I knew they were trying to do this from day one, and now they're finally succeeding. Still, hearing other queer people discuss this issue made me feel less alone in this fight. Hearing you all talk has also solidified in my mind, the importance of lifting up black queer voices as they are the first ones to fight, and they are the first to die, unfortunately. It is time we change that. Thank you for all you do Olay ‚ù§

P.s. thank you for giving a tribute to O'Shae Sibley, I haven't seen nearly enough people talk about it. Also, to my knowledge, his name was spelled O'Shae, but I could be wrong.

author: @angiem6383
text:
Thank you Olay for gathering together this lovely panel. I first saw u on the Leftist Mafia & subscribed to you channel & eagerly await your videos. I'm sorry for all the psychic pain u had to endure while dealing w/ the crappy, (incorrectly) judgement BS that maliciously came (& comes) your way. Thank u for all the knowledge & experiences u shared w/us. Do u know if there's a clip of your experience of dealing our immigration system? I would like to share it. You are sorely missed.
Thanks to the panelists for sharing their experience and expertise in this topic.
RIP O'shea Sibley. I'm sorry our culture /.   Society couldn't let you and your message flourish, a message you should have never had to take on as a burden. Thank you for your work and your joy.

author: @jackiemorris3750
text:
I love the conversation towards the end on how you show up. As someone who is in a town that believes heavily in black people showing up for movements in one kind of way(Charlottesville VA) I have always felt inadequate in how I move. Some avenues for me, don‚Äôt feel organic. Aug 11, 12th 2017 (look up what happened in cville that day if you don‚Äôt know) were regular work days for me. But I carry a guilt that I didn‚Äôt show up enough. That I wasn‚Äôt outside. That I carried fear to be outside. Even when I necessarily didn‚Äôt need to be.

I say all this to say, Hope spoke so passionately and eloquently to the fact that work has been done, and sustaining work is now the move. I‚Äôm still young and I have to remind myself I am still acquiring skills to contribute to the work. But also, I believe that everyone has a role they can play that suits them in this movement. When playing mafia, everybody can‚Äôt be mafia members. Somebody has to be a mayor, and a doctor, and so forth. 

So thank you for saying that part too. Cause that cripples the black folks that are acknowledging realities, having difficult conversations, aaannnddd trying to maintain a sense of joy in their lives. All while dealing with the bullshit.

author: @pbbbtttt8185
text:
acknowledging the ways that race + gender interact is a MAJOR part of changing how we see gender as a whole. so many transphobes act like there's a Universal Female Experience that's required to be a woman and it's absurd.

being white, i'm gonna experience womanhood differently than a black woman, but we're both still women. being autistic, i'm gonna experience womanhood differently than a neurotypical woman, but we're both STILL WOMEN.

our current concepts of gender are very narrow. if we uphold that and pretend there's only one way to be, all for the sake of excluding trans people, we are excluding EVERYONE ELSE that falls outside of that.

anyways. had to get that off my chest. love the video.

author: @therightpodcast6403
text:
Where are the accomplices? I largely agree with this and admit that I could be included in the critique. The idea of "elevate" is problematic. As stated, it frames things in such a way as to suggest there is a need for help from allies. I think help is always welcome but in a way it reminded me of the white savior trope. Not everyone who engages in this is white but it's the power dynamic. I also feel like in these dynamics there is a role of "translator" as well. As if the people listening couldn't possibly understand what the people doing the work are saying. There's a lot to dissect in that observation.

Whiteness is an ideology. I thought this critique was so spot on. The intersectional critique of power dynamics (or lack of them) relating to the script. I might argue that black men and women have been included in masculine and feminine definitions but only in a negative, pejorative way to compare white purity/supremacy against. Perhaps that's another way of saying the same thing.

To allow homophobia, they make it white. Another awesome critique. I think of this in a global perspective as well. Instead of white it is western (implied regardless.) So, hatred, repressive laws, institutionalized homophobia etc. is justified by it being "western" which could be seen as simply making it an "other" within the false framework of anti-imperialism.

This video was all excellent. The inclusion of "How you show up" is so important. I feel like there are many great critiques available but that some of them don't directly communicate things that are actionable. The fact this was done in an introspective way was enlightening.

replies.author: @satyasyasatyasya5746
replies.text:
@HighAsHeckPriestess What I mean is, if you watch David, Mike and Matt on their own channels, and then watch TLM, the topics discussed have already been covered on their own shows and then they just say what they already said again. It seems a little tedious. 
That, and they don't seem to go into much depth or bring anything new to the show like say, taking turns to research something and present it to the group or something.

Also, I find the conversation often decends into "yeh being a content creator is hard but its ok to take breaks/self care/block people etc." and I'm like, sure, ok, but they way y'all keep bringing it up its like you're just soothing eachother and dealing with some impostor syndrome which... should maybe be a little private?

Just my thoughts. They do them, its fine.

text: I think Deshuan would like this one punk band called Fever 333. They have a song where they talk about dismantling the structures of Christianity because its a huge part of oppression in the black community.
